top_comment.text:
So why does this game get a break, but Pac-Man and the Ghostly Adventures 
doesn't? Because of a license? If so then why the strong words about not 
giving a licensed game a break in Green Lantern? *confused*﻿
top_comment.author: James “DigitalAtlas” Cobb

comments.text:
+James Cobb They're not similar in quality, it's fairly clear the SpongeBob 
game is helded in higher regards in terms of it's quality. Just look at the 
overall fan response + reviews. Derek didn't give it a break, he thought 
the game was well done and therefore gave it a good review.
comments.author: Jack McCaffrey

comments.text:
I can understand what you're saying, but Derek wasn't having fun with The 
Ghostly Adventures and he appeared to have fun with Battle for Bikini 
Bottom. He wasn't giving this game a break, either. He stated that even 
beyond the novelty of this being a Spongebob game where most of the main 
cast lend their voices to their roles, there's a good time to be had with 
this game. Plus, he even said that Ghostly Adventures 2 was a lot better 
than the first, so take that what you will.
comments.author: DurradonXylles

comments.text:
But it doesn't matter if one is licensed and one is not if the quality is 
the same. I'm not going to recommend someone Spongebob over Pac-Man if the 
quality of both titles is similar just because the former is licensed. It's 
just simple- if the quality of both is the same, then I treat them the 
same. Expectations don't matter because expectations don't exist in an 
after market. I don't look at SpongeBob with wide-eyes for being passable 
because it's a license game and shame Pac-Man because it's not. If they're 
both fun and similar quality, they should be treated the same.

Also, Derek stated in his Green Lantern review that licensed games don't 
get a break just for being licensed games. Hence my confusion.
comments.author: James “DigitalAtlas” Cobb

comments.text:
I second +tadtad. Also, Derek stated that the movement and controls were 
solid in both Ghostly Adventures games, so it's not like he was just 
bashing the games simply to bash them. You would expect a game licensed 
from a cartoon like Spongebob to be a half-baked cash-in. Pac-Man is one of 
the most recognizable video game icons of all time, and has been in and 
starred in a good number of games. You'd expect the games he's in to have 
at least some sort of appeal, even if they're licensed from a television 
show that's based off of him. That was Derek's point in his reviews of the 
Ghostly Adventure games.
comments.author: DurradonXylles

comments.text:
Maybe this game seems better because it's a licensed game, so the 
expectations are lower.  Pac-Man is one of the most iconic video game 
characters ever, so you expect more from him.
comments.author: tadtad

comments.author: ILikeDoom

comments.text:
I remember my parent's bought the game for me for Christmas one year 
because they found it on sale or something, and when I opened it they asked 
me if I wanted to take it back since it was a kids game. I told them no, 
I'd go ahead and keep/play it, and I ended up loving it lol.

What I really liked about it was the fact that it did have almost the 
entire Spongebob world. As a kid watching the show, that's something I 
always wanted to do--explore it. This game made my dreams come true after a 
long, long, wait. Want to go to Rock Bottom? Jump off the edge of town! 
Wanted to go to the Krusty Krab? Just walk inside! It's something most 
games like this don't do. Typically they give you generic platforming 
(which most of the time isn't fun), and give you levels that are either 
semi based off of areas in a show/movie, or completely "original" stages 
which have nothing to do with anything. This one didn't do that, and I love 
it for that.

captions.text:
Every time we review a game based on a cartoon,
there’s at least 20 people in the comments

telling us to review Battle for Bikini Bottom.
Like, every single time. We even take bets

on how many people are gonna say it, and for
a long time, I didn’t understand idea why.
Now that I’ve played it, I understand why.

I’ve also lost a lot of money. Heat up the
holographic meatloaf, it’s Battle for Bikini
Bottom.

I think there are a couple reasons people
seem to hold this game in such high regard.

And the biggest one, to me…is that a lot
of those people identify this game with their

childhood. Like, I’m sure a lot of you are
like, “Oh, that game was my childhood!”

Which is bizarre to me, ‘cause I’m finally
on the other side of the old guy fence, you
know?
And that sucks.

But it also means I can look at this game
without the hazy fog of nostalgia clouding

my judgment. And that’s the thing, that’s
the second reason people like this one so
much.

Even without the nostalgia, even on its own
merits…this is still a pretty solid game.
About a pretty porous sponge.

So you play as Spongebob, you can also play
as Patrick and Sandy…and basically, it’s

a standard 3D platformer in the tradition
of Super Mario 64. There are lots of different

places, each with lots of objectives…and
you do those things by platforming and collecting

things. Generally, if it shines, you should
collect it, and if it moves, you should kill
it.
Lessons you should also apply to life.

So the design is kind of predictable, but
it’s predictability well done, you know?

Like, there’s actually some fun platforming
in this game. And since the game plays well,

too, it’s a lot more fun than most licensed
games. Even if it’s not doing anything that
great conceptually.

And you know, I think one of the game’s
strengths is its pacing. Like, you can just

run through the levels, and along the way,
you’ll be able to finish most of the objectives.

Without very much time, or exploration…the
game doesn’t drag as much as licensed 3D

games sometimes can. There are golden spatulas
all over the place, so it moves pretty quickly.

Which is good. That way, you don’t get bored.
You’re not spending an hour on the same

objective, and especially for a game for kids,
that’s definitely the right approach to
take.

The game really does play well, too. And that’s
something that really hurts a lot of platformers.

Like, if your controls and mechanics aren’t
solid, stuff like this can be a nightmare.

But this one gets it. And again, it’s standard
stuff—butt stomp, double jump, spin attack…but

it’s all done well. You never struggle with
bad controls, which was a pleasant surprise.

And it sounds so obvious, but that’s the
most important thing in a platformer. Everything

else is secondary to the controls. To how
the game plays. And Battle for Bikini Bottom
plays just fine.

The presentation’s not bad, either. I mean,
it’s a little PS2-tastic…2003 textures,

things like that…but for its time, and for
its platform, it’s not bad. And actually,

the main character models are really well
done, and there are some good animations,

too. But of course, the big thing is they
got most of the cast to do the voices, which
includes Tom Kenny as Spongebob.

Although, I would like to hear someone else
try Spongebob.

Someone totally different. Like, I want to
hear Morgan Freeman, as Spongebob.

It’s not like Tom Kenny needs 
the work, anyway.

Alright, so it’s official. I’ve played
Battle for Bikini Bottom, I’ve had the experience.

And here’s the thing, I can’t say it’s
the most amazing thing ever…and I still

think half of the reason people seem to love
it is they loved being a kid, and they remember

it from being a kid…but even with its bland
design, and occasionally wonky camera, seriously,
Spongebob, get the hell out of the way…
This is a quality licensed game.

There, we reviewed it. It’s Battle for Bikini
Bottom.
Spongebob, you’re making this very uncomfortable.

title: CGR Undertow - SPONGEBOB SQUAREPANTS: BATTLE FOR BIKINI BOTTOM review for PlayStation 2
